section.title: Relative clauses
section.sectiontitle: Defining relative clauses make it clear who/what we are referring to. They cannot be omitted from the sentence.
section.text1a: That's the team which won the tournament.
section.text2a: He's the man who sold me this guitar.
section.sectiontitle2: If the relative pronoun (who/what/which, etc.) is the object of the clause, it can be omitted.
section.text3: He's the man who we saw yesterday!
section.text3a: He's the man we saw yesterday!
section.text4: That's the cake which I wanted.

section.title: Relative clauses
section.sectiontitle: With defining relative clauses, that can replace who or which.
section.text1: The woman who I met was a spy!
section.text1a: The woman that I met was a spy!
section.text2: Those coins which you've been collecting are worthless.
section.text2a: Those coins that you've been collecting are worthless.
section.sectiontitle2: Non-defining relative clauses give extra information. The sentence still makes sense if we omit the extra information.
section.text3: We went on a boat trip, which was fun.
section.text3a: We went on a boat trip.
section.text4: I bumped into Donald, who was wearing his hat as usual.

section.title: Relative clauses
section.sectiontitle: With non-defining relative clauses, that cannot replace who or which.  The relative pronoun cannot be omitted.
section.text1a: I saw your brother, who was already late.
section.sectiontitle2: When the relative clause uses verb + dependent preposition the preposition usually goes at the end of the clause, but in formal English it can go at the beginning.
section.text3: That's the theory which my thesis was based on.
section.text3a: That's the theory on which my thesis was based.
section.text4: That's the radio programme which she listens to.
section.text4a: That's the radio programme to which she listens.

section.title: Relative clauses
section.sectiontitle: We can use one/some/all/either/neither ... of which/whom. This pattern is slightly formal.
section.text1a: I met the five Davies brothers, all of whom swim well.
section.text2a: She visited two flats, neither of which she liked.
